title: Trade Secret Analysis: Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory

I.title: Trade Secret Definition Under Federal Law

1.statute: 18 USC § 1839(3) (financial, business, scientific, technical, economic, or engineering information, including patterns, plans, compilations, program devices, formulas, designs, prototypes, methods, techniques, processes, procedures, programs, or codes)

sub_elements.c: not readily ascertainable through proper means
sub_elements.d: others can obtain economic value from disclosure/use

II.title: Trade Secret Misappropriation Under Federal Law
II.case_law_framework: Two broad categories: (1) Improper Means and (2) Confidential Relationship

A.title: Acquisition by Improper Means
A.case_authority: E.I. DuPont deNemours & Co. v. Christopher (5th Cir. 1970)
A.case_facts: Defendants hired to take aerial photographs of DuPont's under-construction methanol plant to reveal secret manufacturing process
A.case_holding: Aerial photography of plant construction constitutes improper means; 'means which fall below the generally accepted standards of commercial morality and reasonable conduct'

elements.1: acquisition of trade secret of another
elements.2: person knows or has reason to know trade secret was acquired by improper means

elements.1: disclosure or use of trade secret without express or implied consent

ii.case_facts: Dravo entered negotiations to purchase Smith's container business, received detailed confidential info including patents/blueprints/customer lists, then rejected purchase but used info to develop competing product
ii.case_holding: Confidential relationship implied from limited purpose of disclosure (purchase negotiations); 'trust reposed' creates duty not to use information beyond negotiation purpose

sub_categories.I: derived from person who used improper means
sub_categories.II: acquired under circumstances giving rise to duty of secrecy/limited use
sub_categories.III: derived from person who owed duty of secrecy to owner

C.title: Improper Means Definition
C.case_elaboration: DuPont v. Christopher: 'Commercial privacy must be protected from espionage which could not have been reasonably anticipated or prevented'
C.includes: theft, bribery, misrepresentation, breach or inducement of breach of duty to maintain secrecy, espionage
C.excludes: reverse engineering, independent derivation, other lawful means

III.title: Analysis: Is the Everlasting Gobstopper a Trade Secret?
III.analysis_framework: Apply 18 USC § 1839(3) three-element test to the gobstopper

threshold_issue.title: Focus of Analysis
threshold_issue.rationale: Analysis must focus on whether the gobstopper itself qualifies as a trade secret, as this is what the child gave to Slugworth
threshold_issue.scope: While the manufacturing formula/process may also be trade secrets, the gobstopper is the subject of the alleged misappropriation

A.title: Element 1: Information Type (Subject Matter)

prototype_theory.description: Physical gobstopper qualifies as 'prototype' under federal statute
prototype_theory.support: Wonka's statement: 'At least, I don't think they do a few more tests' indicates ongoing development
prototype_theory.legal_significance: Prototype explicitly enumerated in 18 USC § 1839(3); development status strengthens protection

dupont_parallel.case_authority: E.I. DuPont deNemours & Co. v. Christopher (5th Cir. 1970)
dupont_parallel.comparison: Like aerial photographs of under-construction plant that revealed secret process, physical gobstopper embodies/reveals secret formula
dupont_parallel.legal_analysis: DuPont photographs were protectable despite being 'just pictures' - they contained/revealed trade secret information. Similarly, gobstopper 'contains' secret formula
dupont_parallel.distinction: Gobstopper has even stronger protection as enumerated 'prototype' rather than mere embodiment of secret

A.conclusion: Gobstopper qualifies under federal law both as prototype and as information embodying trade secrets

B.title: Element 2: Reasonable Measures to Keep Secret
facts_to_analyze: Factory sealed for years: 'Nobody ever goes in, nobody ever comes out'
Inventing Room locked and marked 'KEEP OUT'
Machine covered with fabric marked 'KEEP OUT'
Warning: 'No Touching, No Tasting, No Telling!'
Required solemn oath: 'never show them to another living soul'
B.case_comparison: DuPont v. Christopher - DuPont not required to put roof over under-construction plant; Wonka's extensive precautions far exceed reasonable measures standard
B.conclusion: Wonka's multi-layered secrecy measures clearly satisfy reasonable precautions requirement

C.title: Element 3: Independent Economic Value from Secrecy
facts_to_analyze: Wonka's statement: 'If he succeeds, he'll ruin me' (Slugworth)
Commercial viability: 'For children with very little pocket money'
Slugworth's willingness to pay $10,000 + house + lifetime support
C.legal_analysis: Clear evidence of actual and potential economic value derived from secrecy; competitive significance demonstrated by Slugworth's fear and payment offer

IV.title: Analysis: Slugworth's Liability for Trade Secret Misappropriation

acquisition_element.facts: Slugworth obtained Everlasting Gobstopper from child through bribery/inducement before public release, then reverse engineered formula

facts: Knew Wonka was developing secret invention
Offered large payment for secret formula
Knew children would breach oath of secrecy
knowledge_element.legal_analysis: Actual knowledge that trade secret acquired by improper means (inducement of breach of duty)
knowledge_element.case_comparison: Similar to DuPont v. Christopher - Slugworth engaged in commercial espionage by inducing breach of confidential relationship

B.title: Improper Means Analysis
facts: Bribery: $10,000 + house + lifetime support offered to child
Inducement of breach of duty: Children swore oath never to show gobstopper to 'another living soul'
B.conclusion: Improper means established via bribery and inducement of breach of duty
B.case_comparison: Unlike DuPont (aerial photography), here bribery is explicit statutory improper means under 18 USC § 1839(6)(A)

reverse_engineering_distinction.lawful_alternative: Slugworth could have lawfully reverse engineered gobstopper AFTER public release under 18 USC § 1839(6)(B)
reverse_engineering_distinction.timing_issue: Problem is pre-market acquisition through improper means (bribery/inducement), not the reverse engineering itself
reverse_engineering_distinction.legal_analysis: Timing matters: reverse engineering released products = lawful; inducing breach to obtain unreleased products = improper means

C.title: Use Without Consent
C.facts: Slugworth manufactured and sold competing gobstoppers without Wonka's consent, before Wonka's public release
C.timing_significance: Use occurred before trade secret owner could commercialize, distinguishing from post-release reverse engineering

V.title: Analysis: Child's Liability for Trade Secret Misappropriation

disclosure_element.facts: Child gave Everlasting Gobstopper to Slugworth

consent_element.facts: No express or implied consent from Wonka; violated explicit oath

B.title: Knowledge Analysis
facts: Child acquired gobstopper 'under circumstances giving rise to duty to maintain secrecy'
Explicit oath: 'solemnly swear to keep them for yourselves and never show them to another living soul'
Child knew Slugworth was competitor seeking secret formula
B.legal_analysis: Child knew trade secret acquired under duty of secrecy and knew of duty to limit use
B.case_comparison: Similar to Smith v. Dravo confidential relationship - child received gobstopper for limited purpose (personal use only) with express oath creating duty

C.title: Alternative Theory: Breach of Duty
C.analysis: Child derived knowledge from Wonka who owed no duty, but child directly owed duty to Wonka based on oath

A.title: Trade Secret Status
A.conclusion: Everlasting Gobstopper formula qualifies as trade secret under 18 USC § 1839(3)

B.title: Slugworth Liability
B.conclusion: Strong case for misappropriation under 18 USC § 1839(5)(A) - acquisition by improper means (bribery/inducement category)

C.title: Child Liability
C.conclusion: Strong case for misappropriation under 18 USC § 1839(5)(B)(ii)(II) - disclosure with knowledge of duty to maintain secrecy (confidential relationship category)
